citations.narrative:
The wooden shelter inside the enclosure housing 2 yellow-naped parrots has multiple areas where it is excessively
chewed and splintered. The wooden shelter is no longer structurally sound and rough, splintered wood poses a risk of
injury to animals as they move throughout the shelter. Housing facilities for birds must be designed and constructed so
that they are structurally sound for the species of bird housed in them. They must be kept in good repair and protect the
birds from injury. The wood must be repaired or replaced when worn. Correct by March 15,2024.

citations.desc: Access and inspection of records and property; submission of itineraries.
citations.narrative:
At the time of inspection, the contingency plan, an updated program of veterinary care, and environmental enhancement
program for birds, were still not available for review by the inspector. Review of records required by the Animal Welfare
Act facilitates the inspection process by allowing the inspector to determine compliance and evaluate animal welfare. The
facility shall ensure that the records required to be kept by the Animal Welfare Act and the regulations are available for
USDA APHIS officials to examine.

The enclosures housing 1 red-tailed hawk, 2 chickens, 1 green heron, 1 barred owl, and 1 grackle did not have adequate
shelter from inclement weather. Failure to provide adequate shelter from inclement weather can lead to the animals'
discomfort or injury. Outdoor housing facilities must provide adequate shelter to protect birds from any adverse weather
conditions. Shelters must be adequately ventilated in hot weather and have one or more separate areas of shade or other
effective protection that is large enough to comfortably contain all the birds at one time and prevent their discomfort from
direct sunlight, precipitation, or wind. Correct by April 5th, 2024.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with a facility representative.
n

narrative:
3.150(a) 
   
Facilities, general. 
The wooden shelter inside the enclosure housing 2 yellow-naped parrots has multiple areas where it is excessively 
chewed and splintered. The wooden shelter is no longer structurally sound and rough, splintered wood poses a risk of 
injury to animals as they move throughout the shelter. Housing facilities for birds must be designed and constructed so 
that they are structurally sound for the species of bird housed in them. They must be kept in good repair and protect the 
birds from injury. The wood must be repaired or replaced when worn. Correct by March 15,2024. 
2.126(a)(2)  Repeat
   
Access and inspection of records and property; submission of itineraries. 
At the time of inspection, the contingency plan, an updated program of veterinary care, and environmental enhancement 
program for birds, were still not available for review by the inspector. Review of records required by the Animal Welfare 
Act facilitates the inspection process by allowing the inspector to determine compliance and evaluate animal welfare. The 
facility shall ensure that the records required to be kept by the Animal Welfare Act and the regulations are available for 
USDA APHIS officials to examine. 
3.152(b) 
   
Facilities, outdoor 
The enclosures housing 1 red-tailed hawk, 2 chickens, 1 green heron, 1 barred owl, and 1 grackle did not have adequate 
shelter from inclement weather. Failure to provide adequate shelter from inclement weather can lead to the animals' 
discomfort or injury. Outdoor housing facilities must provide adequate shelter to protect birds from any adverse weather 
conditions. Shelters must be adequately ventilated in hot weather and have one or more separate areas of shade or other 
effective protection that is large enough to comfortably contain all the birds at one time and prevent their discomfort from 
direct sunlight, precipitation, or wind. Correct by April 5th, 2024. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with a facility representative.
